comment.bubble:
Most coding languages allow you to leave comments in your code. In CSS you can create a comment by starting it with /* and ending with */. Code are instructions, it's how you tell the browser what you want it to display, but browsers ignore comments. Comments are for people, not machines.

Coders use them for all sorts of reasons, most often for leaving notes explaining how the code works (future you will thank you for that). It's also a great way to credit any code snippets you've copy+pasted from somewhere else. They can also be used to "comment out" code, so that the browser ignores it temporarily without having to remove it.

The shortcut key CTRL+/ (control forward-slash), or CMD+/ (command forward-slash) on Mac, can be used to comment out lines of code.

clip-path.bubble: The clip-path property can be used to "clip" or "mask" certain regions of an element. It's a great way of transforming elements into all sorts of different shapes. Learn more about it at css-tricks.com. We're working on widgets that make it easier to use properties like these, but in the meantime checkout this great clip-path generator!

vw.bubble:
vw stands for "viewport width", the viewport is the "viewable portion" of your document, meaning everything you currently see in your window. You can think of vw as a percentage of the window's width (as opposed to the % which is always relative to the parent element).

when numbers are highlighted you can use the up/down arrow keys to adjust this value, hold the Shift key to adjust by 10.

vh stands for "viewport height", the viewport is the "viewable portion" of your document, meaning everything you currently see in your window. You can think of vh as a percentage of the window's height (as opposed to the % which is always relative to the parent element).

%.bubble:
% is a "percentage" value, often used to define a size or position relative to an element's parent element.

when numbers are highlighted you can use the up/down arrow keys to adjust this value, hold the Shift key to adjust by 10.

em.bubble:
em is a unit of length which relates directly to font size. For example, if font-size: 10px; than width: 2em; would be a width of 20px. When applied to font-size: 1em; then it's relative to the inherited font-size, usually it's parent element's. Read more about em and similar units.

when numbers are highlighted you can use the up/down arrow keys to adjust this value, hold the Shift key to adjust by 10.

rem.bubble:
rem is a unit of length which relates directly to font size of the "root" element (the <html>) which essentially means the browser's default font-size. For example, assuming the user has their browser's font-size set to 16px, a width: 2em; would equate to 32px. Read more about rem and similar units.

when numbers are highlighted you can use the up/down arrow keys to adjust this value, hold the Shift key to adjust by 10.

ch.bubble:
ch is a unit of length which equates to the width of teh character 0, so width: 2em; would be the width of 2 zeroes. This can change depending on the font-family you're using. Read more about ch and similar units.

when numbers are highlighted you can use the up/down arrow keys to adjust this value, hold the Shift key to adjust by 10.

px.bubble:
